notes: Home to the first imaged black hole, M87*, discovered in 2019.
Discovered in 1773. Famous for its spiral structure.
Edge-on spiral galaxy with a bright core and dark dust lane.
Known since ancient times. First described by al-Sufi in 964 AD.
Discovered by Maraldi in 1746, catalogued by Messier in 1760.
Discovered by Messier in 1764. Contains about 500,000 stars.
Discovered by Messier in 1764. Compact and faint.
Discovered by Kirch in 1702, added to Messier's catalog in 1764.
Discovered by Messier in 1764. One of the brighter globulars.
One of the closest globular clusters to Earth.
Remnant of a supernova observed in 1054 AD. Catalogued by Messier in 1758.
Discovered by Le Gentil in 1747. Star-forming region.
Known since antiquity, resembles a butterfly in shape.
Brightest diffuse nebula. Described in 1610 by Peiresc.
Known to Ptolemy in 130 AD. Bright open cluster.
Also known as Seven Sisters. Visible to the naked eye.
